abstract.p: This study investigates the structural invariance of the Achievement Goal Questionnaire (AGQ) in American, Chinese, and Dutch college students. Using confirmatory factor analyses (CFA), the authors found evidence for the four-factor structure of achievement goals in all three samples. Subsequent multigroup CFAs supported structural invariance of the AGQ across the samples.

body.p: In the last two decades, achievement goals have played a prominent role in the achievement motivation literature (Elliot & McGregor, 2001; Van Yperen, 2006). Goals have been conceptualized as individuals’ cognitive representations of competence-based outcomes that emerge when they approach, experience, and respond to achievement situations in a variety of contexts such as the classroom, the work place, and the sports field (Cury, Elliot, Da Fonséca, & Moller, 2006). The theoretical underpinnings and operationalization of achievement goals have followed a long history. Conceptually, the constructs have developed from a focus on one dimension of competence (i.e., mastery vs. performance; Dweck & Leggett, 1988) to the inclusion of a second dimension related to the valence of these competence cognitions (i.e., approach vs. avoidance; Elliot & Harakiewicz, 1996).

Likewise, the hypothesized structure of achievement goals has evolved from a dichotomous form of performance versus mastery (Ames & Archer, 1988; Dweck & Leggett, 1988; Nicholls, 1984), through a trichotomous framework of performance approach, performance avoidance, and mastery goals (Elliot & Church, 1997; Elliot & Harackiewicz, 1996), to the most recent 2 × 2 framework of performance approach, performance avoidance, mastery approach, and mastery avoidance (Conroy, Elliot, & Hofer, 2003; Elliot & McGregor, 2001). From a classroom perspective, students with mastery goals are mostly concerned with doing well in the achievement task presented to them. In contrast, students with performance goals mostly focus on how well they perform relative to others, and they tend to use this information as a competence indicator. Competence might also vary in terms of valence. Approach goals mobilize individuals to achieve positive outcomes, whereas avoidance goals motivate individuals to avoid negative outcomes (Elliot & McGregor, 2001). In general, achievement goals are related to motivational tendencies such as need for success and fear of failure and predict behavioral and motivational outcomes such as intrinsic motivation and academic performance (Elliot & Murayama, 2008).

sec.title: Cross-Cultural Research in Achievement Goal Theory
sec.p: Cross-cultural research on self-construals or individuals’ subjective perceptions of the world around them seems to suggest that several Western cultures, mostly located in North America and Europe, can be described as more individualistic, whereas other cultures, usually found in East Asian and Latin American countries, can be described as more collectivistic (e.g., Fiske, Kitayama, Markus, & Nisbett, 1998; Kim, Triandis, Kagitcibasi, Choi, & Yoon, 1994; Markus & Kitayama, 1991, among others). In individualistic cultures the self is seen as more independent, and individuals organize their behaviors using their internal states (emotions, beliefs, thoughts, etc.) as their guiding reference. In consequence, individuals are perceived as more autonomous, since their actions represent their personal motivations, and social responsiveness takes on the role of providing a standard for assertion and self-appraisal (Markus & Kitayama, 1991). In contrast, more collectivistic cultures see the self as dependent on its connections with others and the level of relatedness to them. Individuals see themselves as interdependent on other members of the culture. Therefore, the interdependent self acquires meaning in its relationship to others, and the quality of these relationships is the primary source of self-esteem and internal consistency. Furthermore, because individuals can only evaluate their relationships to others in specific contexts, “internal attributes are understood as situation specific, and thus as sometimes elusive and unreliable” (Markus & Kitayama, 1991, p. 227).

Urdan (2004) argues that differential findings should be expected on achievement goals between highly collectivistic and individualistic cultures. Cultures that emphasize ego processes may differ with respect to performance goals from more collectivistic cultures. In other words, if the social environment does not value, or otherwise penalizes social comparisons, then individuals in a collectivistic society may be less likely to endorse performance goals compared with individuals in highly individualistic environments. Furthermore, collectivistic individuals may engage in more avoidance regulation processes compared with members of more individualistic groups (Elliot, Chirkov, Kim, & Sheldon, 2001). That is, individuals may be more motivated to endorse failure avoidance goals when they perceive that their personal success is heavily linked to the success of the group, or when individuals are in highly evaluative environments.

Some international and cross-cultural studies conducted using achievement goal theory and the Achievement Goal Questionnaire (AGQ; Elliot & McGregor, 2001) identify possible cultural variations along the individualism/collectivism dimension. Tanaka and Yamauchi (2001) explored achievement goals in a sample of Japanese students. They found that mastery goals were positively related to intrinsic interest and academic achievement, while performance approach and performance avoidance goals were unrelated to both constructs. These results differ from the traditional and the more recent achievement goal literature (Elliot & Church, 1997; Elliot & Murayama, 2008), which posits that intrinsic motivation should be positively associated to mastery goals and negatively to performance avoidance goal. In addition, in American samples, achievement (e.g., exam performance) is usually positively related to performance approach goal and negatively related to performance avoidance goal. In a follow-up study, Tanaka, Okuno, and Yamauchi (2002) also found a positive relationship between performance avoidance goal and achievement for Japanese students.

Researchers also identified some cross-cultural differences with regard to interfactor correlations. In a study comparing Japanese and American samples, Murayama (2003) found a higher correlation between performance approach and performance avoidance goals in the Japanese sample, compared with the American sample. This finding was later replicated when comparing a Japanese sample and a Canadian sample (Murayama, Zhou, & Nesbit, 2009). Authors of both articles have argued that Japanese students seem to differentiate less between approach and avoidance goals compared with their more individualistic counterparts. In addition, Canadian students also seem to endorse all achievement goals more strongly compared with Japanese students, which can be an indication of group differences in social desirability biases or self-enhancement needs (Murayama et al., 2009). However, despite these differences, Murayama et al. (2009) were able to provide support for the metric invariance of the 2 × 2 achievement goal model, using the AGQ. This finding indicates that although goals can be expressed and endorsed differently in both cultures, the underlying constructs were found to be the same between the samples (Murayama et al., 2009). This finding has also been supported by other studies, which in contrast to the tenets of sociocultural theory validate the universality of goals and values (Grouzet et al., 2005; Schwartz & Bilsky, 1990).

Despite the growing interest in comparing the achievement goals across the cultures, there is still a dearth of rigorous cross-cultural validation of the instruments measuring the achievement goals. When comparisons are made on achievement goals across cultures, it is critical that the measures have to be psychometrically sound across cultures (Steenkamp & Baumgarten, 1998) and that the underlying constructs have the same theoretical structure and operate in similar ways across cultures (Dimitrov, 2010). Otherwise it is not possible to determine whether observed item differences are due to latent mean differences (true differences) or differential psychometric responses to the scale items (measurement artifact). Researchers doing cross-cultural studies have shown tremendous concern for measurement equivalence of scales across cultures and have called for more cross-cultural validation work (e.g., Matsumoto & Yoo, 2006). Although many studies involving cross-cultural validation of achievement goals have used exploratory factor analysis, there has been a growing trend toward using confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) for cross-cultural validation of such scales (Murayama et al., 2009). Hopwood and Donnellan (2010) have argued that CFA may suppress factorial cross-loadings that usually emerge on exploratory analyses. However, CFA is a more advantageous technique that allows researchers to determine a more parsimonious model by specifying the factor structures and appropriate error variances driven by theory, prior research evidence, and substantive significance (Bollen, 1989; Brown, 2006). More important, multigroup CFA offers a very strong addition for evaluating the invariance of measurement models across distinct groups, which is an essential procedure to collect evidence of instrument validity across cultures (see Brown 2006; Byrne, 2006). However, this procedure is often underused (Dimitrov, 2010). To the authors’ knowledge, there is only one study that employed multigroup CFA to establish measurement invariance of the AGQ between two cultures (Murayama et al., 2009), and no studies exist that include a sample of participants from the Netherlands.

The purpose of this study was twofold: (a) to investigate whether the 2 × 2 model of achievement goals is superior to the two- and three-factor models in three samples of American, Chinese, and Dutch college students and (b) to examine the measurement invariance of the AGQ across these three samples.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The American sample consisted of 179 students (78.2% females) from a southwest public university who were enrolled in a general education course in lifespan development. The mean age (standard deviation) of the participants was 19.8 years (SD = 2.21). A total of 488 freshmen and sophomore students (41.8% females) from three public universities in China also participated in this study. These students were enrolled in a general education course in English in each university. The participants had an average of 19.7 years (SD = 1.11). Data were also collected from 84 students (88.0% females) from a Dutch university who were enrolled in a psychology class (M = 21.5, SD = 2.92).

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: The AGQ (see Table 1 for the English, Chinese, and Dutch versions of the AGQ) is a 12-item instrument designed to measure performance approach goal (i.e., actively seeking to gain positive judgments of a performance in relation to others; Items 1, 7, 8), performance avoidance goal (i.e., passively avoiding negative judgments of a performance in relation to others; Items 2, 5, 10), mastery approach goal (i.e., a desire to increase knowledge or understanding through effort; Items 3, 9,12), and mastery avoidance goal (i.e., striving to avoid failing to learn course materials; Items 4, 6, 11). Participants responded to the items using a Likert-type scale, ranging from 1 (does not correspond at all) to 7 (corresponds exactly), with a higher score indicating a stronger orientation toward each achievement goal. For the Chinese version, one Chinese/English bilingual translated the original English version of AGQ into Chinese, and another Chinese/English bilingual back-translated the Chinese version (Brislin, 1980). No major discrepancies were found by comparing the original English version and the back-translated version. For the Dutch version, two Dutch/English bilinguals translated the English version to Dutch independently and compared with each other’s translation. Consensus was reached on the final word choice for a few synonyms. Both translations followed the guidelines of consistency in terminology and clarity and equivalency in conceptual meaning.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: A CFA was conducted to determine the underlying structure of achievement goals for the American, Chinese, and Dutch study samples, using the structural equation modeling software program EQS 6 (Bentler, 2004). First, the four-factor model identified by Elliot and McGregor (2001) was tested independently against the competing two- and three-factor models for each sample. Given the good fit of the four-factor model for each sample, multigroup CFAs were performed to evaluate the level of measurement invariance across the three groups. Following the method described in Brown (2006), configural invariance, metric invariance, scalar invariance, and structural invariance across the samples were tested in that order. Dimitrov (2010) has also referred to metric invariance as weak measurement invariance and scalar invariance as strong measurement invariance. Cases with missing values were deleted listwise in all analyses. Only 1.7% of the American sample, 3.5% of the Chinese sample, and 2.4% of the Dutch sample contained missing values for any of the items.

The model fit was evaluated using the chi-square statistic (χ2) and other descriptive fit indices including the root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA; Steiger, 1990) and its 90% confidence interval and the comparative fit index (CFI; Bentler, 1990). We considered a cutoff value of CFI to .90 (Bentler, 1990) and an RMSEA index less than .10 (MacCallum, Browne, & Sugawara, 1996) as appropriate model fit. When competing models were nested, the comparative fit was assessed using the CFI difference. We decided to use a CFI decrease greater than .01 (e.g., −.02) as a criterion to reject the null hypothesis of invariance (Cheung & Rensvold, 2002). Evidence shows that χ2 differences are dependent on sample size (Kelloway, 1995) while CFI differences are not (Cheung & Rensvold, 2002) and that χ2 differences are also more susceptible to Type I error inflation than CFI differences (French & Finch, 2011). Chi-square differences were reported as a supplement.

sec.title: Descriptive Statistics and Data Screening
sec.p: Following the recommendations by Zientek and Thompson (2009), means, standard deviations, and bivariate correlation matrices for the 12 AGQ items are reported in Table 2 for each of the three samples. The internal consistency coefficients and their 95% confidence intervals for the four achievement goals and the AGQ are reported in Table 3 for all samples. The reliability coefficients ranged from .73 to .94 with two exceptions. The coefficients were .58 and .67 for the performance avoidance goal for the Chinese and Dutch samples. These results concur with Campbell, Barry, Joe, and Finney’s (2008) finding that the performance avoidance items were less consistent compared with items from the other three subscales for both African American and White students. Nunnally (1967) suggested that a reliability of .60 or .50 would suffice for a hypothesized measure of a construct. Given that each goal is being measured by three items, we considered these reliability coefficients to be acceptable.

sec.p: Univariate normality was assessed by exploring the skewness and the kurtosis of the items. Skewness values ranged from −.92 to .11 with a median of −.43 for the American sample, from −.71 to .47 with a median of .03 for the Chinese sample, and from −1.24 to .36 with a median of −.19 for the Dutch sample. Kurtosis values ranged from −.94 to .52 with a median of −.61 for the American students, from −1.21 to −.28 with a median of −.80 for the Chinese students, and from −1.18 to 2.14 with a median of −.80 for the Dutch students. With the exception of Item 8, which had a marginally higher peak than the normal distribution for the Dutch sample (kurtosis = 2.14), all absolute values of skewness and kurtosis were less than 2, supporting the univariate normality of the data (Finney & DiStefano, 2006). Having established univariate normality, the multivariate normality was assessed using an omnibus test of multivariate normality based on Small’s (1980) statistics. Small’s test reached significance for all three samples. Therefore, we performed a CFA based on the robust maximum likelihood estimation method and reported Satorra–Bentler scaled chi-square (SBS χ2; Satorra & Bentler, 1994).

sec.title: Factor Structure: Testing Alternative Models
sec.p: CFAs were conducted for each sample independently to select the most parsimonious and best fitting factor structure of the AGQ. Based on previous theoretical development and research on goal theory, we compared the following models: (a) two 2-factor models (performance vs. mastery and approach vs. avoidance), (b) one 3-factor model (performance approach, performance avoidance, and mastery), and (c) one 4-factor model (performance approach, performance avoidance, mastery approach, and mastery avoidance). The sample correlation matrices, indicator standard deviations, and/or means were used as input. The error terms were left uncorrelated while the factors were allowed to correlate. The fit statistics of each model are presented in Table 4 for the three samples. The four-factor model demonstrated adequate fit for all three samples, but none of the alternative models provided a good fit to the data.

sec.title: Measurement Invariance
sec.p: Based on the results that the four-factor solution adequately accounted for the structure of the constructs measured by the AGQ, we proceeded to test whether the four-factor model was equivalent across the American, Chinese, and Dutch samples. The invariance testing included an analysis of configural invariance, metric invariance, scalar invariance, and structural invariance with each step imposing a more restrictive level of invariance across the samples (Brown, 2006; Byrne, 2006; Dimitrov, 2010).

sec.title: Configural invariance model
sec.p: The configural invariance model tests whether the basic factor structure is equivalent across the three samples. This level of invariance imposes the minimal constraint on the factorial invariance, namely, there are the same numbers of factors with the same items associated with each factor across the samples (Meredith, 1993). This is to establish a baseline model with which to compare the more restrictive models. Results indicate that the fit of the model was satisfactory (see Table 5), SBS χ2(144, n = 729) = 382.81, p < .01, CFI = .927, RMSEA = .083.

sec.title: Metric invariance model
sec.p: Given the satisfactory fit of the configural invariance model, we proceeded to test the metric invariance model. The metric invariance model tests whether the factor loadings are equal across the samples. As shown in Table 5, the metric invariance model was found to be a good fit to the data, SBS χ2(160, n = 729) = 417.76, p < .01, CFI = .921, RMSEA = .082. The CFI difference between the configural invariance model and the metric invariance model was −.006, indicating that the constraints of equal factor loadings across the samples did not degrade the model fit (Cheung & Rensvold, 2002) and that all the factor loadings could be considered equal across the samples.

sec.title: Scalar invariance model
sec.p: In this analysis, we explored the scalar invariance model for the current samples. That is, whether the item intercepts can also be considered equivalent in addition to the factor loadings. As presented in Table 5, the overall fit for this model was satisfactory, SBS χ2 (184, n = 729) = 811.94, p < .01, CFI = .913, RMSEA = .096. The CFI difference between the scalar invariance model and the metric invariance model was −.007, suggesting that the constraints of equal item intercepts did not degrade the fit of the solution (Cheung & Rensvold, 2002) and that item intercepts could be considered equal across the samples.

sec.title: Structural invariance model
sec.p: Given the evidence of scalar invariance, we proceeded to test the structural invariance across the samples. Structural invariance determines whether the factor variances and covariances are equal across the samples. The structural invariance model yielded adequate model fit, SBS χ2 (196, n = 729) = 893.58, p < .01, CFI = .904, RMSEA = .097 (see Table 5). In contrast to the scalar invariance model, the structural invariance model did not result in a significant degradation of fit, ΔCFI = −.009 (Cheung & Rensvold, 2002). Therefore, we were able to support the structural invariance for the four-factor model across the three samples.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The increasing interest in cross-cultural differences on achievement goal orientation (e.g., Lee, Tinsley, & Bobko, 2003; Xiang, Lee, & Shen, 2001), combined with the scant validity evidence of the instruments assessing these constructs across the cultures, underscores the significance of this type of investigation (Campbell et al., 2008). Our study establishes the structural invariance of the four-factor model of AGQ across samples from the United States, China, and the Netherlands. These findings are consistent with previous research supporting the four-factor model of achievement goals in different cultures (Murayama et al., 2009), as well as the universal structure of values and goals (Grouzet et al., 2005; Schwartz & Bilsky, 1990). Based on our results, one can assume that the four factors have equivalency and the constructs could have similar meanings or serve similar functions across student samples in these three countries. In addition, support for the configural, metric, scalar, and structural invariances also warrant comparisons of item scores between similar samples from these cultures.

The implications for educational practitioners are several. First, it offers validation to the 2 × 2 model of achievement goals in which the mastery and performance dimensions of competence can be explored in contrast with approach and avoidance tendencies. Second, the AGQ can be used across samples of college students in the United States, China, and the Netherlands to explore and compare students’ goals. Derived from the previous two implications is a third connotation. When it comes to exploring students’ goals and using the AGQ, counselors may not necessarily need to customize guidance for students depending on their culture, but instead they may attend more carefully to students’ individual differences and needs.

The support for structural invariance between our samples could suggest that variation between individualistic and collectivistic self-construals may not necessarily affect the underlying structure of achievement goals. However, it is important to consider that in our study we did not measure collectivism and individualism. Therefore, although we can assume, based on previous sociocultural research, that there are certain different preexisting qualities across the cultures in our study, we did not collect evidence to support this assumption. In addition, we use country as a proxy for culture, which may be limited in that context-level variables related to local differences, or contextual variations in the educational institutions where data were collected were ignored. Moreover, although we established structural equivalence between the three cultures, we did not examine response bias at the item level, which some researchers identify as an important issue in cross-cultural comparison research (van de Vijer & Leung, 1997). In this regard, the question remains open as to whether Western samples tend to more consistently endorse all types of goals (Murayama et al., 2009) and East Asian samples are less likely to use extreme scores in Likert-type scales in general (Chen, Lee, & Stevenson, 1995). We agree with other authors (i.e., Murayama, Elliot, & Yamagata, 2011) that future studies should explore more in depth potential problems with systematic item response bias that may be confounded with cross-cultural comparisons in the achievement goal literature.

When interpreting our results, one should keep in mind that our study is subject to several limitations. First, the overall fit statistics such as SBS χ2 and CFI are influenced more heavily by the larger Chinese sample than by the American or Dutch sample (Brown, 2006). We relied on the CFI difference rather than the χ2 difference as a criterion to reject the null hypothesis of invariance, since χ2 difference is more likely to be influenced by sample size (Kelloway, 1995) and is more susceptible to Type I error inflation (French & Finch, 2011). However, we may have lacked enough power to detect parameter estimates that are significantly different for the Dutch sample. Second, our samples are all college students. It has been suggested that the factor structure of the constructs being examined may vary as a function of the samples selected for comparisons (Van de Vijer & Leung, 1997) or the age of the participants (Urdan & Mestas, 2006). Chinese students usually become less concerned with their course grades and competitiveness in academic performance after going to the college, which may make them less likely to pursue performance goals. Also, the Dutch students were enrolled in an upper level class and therefore may be more likely to endorse mastery goals rather than performance goals. It warrants more investigations to see whether the results are replicable with students of different ages (e.g., elementary school students and secondary school students) in these three cultures. Third, in our article we were unable to establish the structural invariance between males and females since the gender compositions were not comparable across our three samples. However, previous studies have supported the measurement invariance of the AGQ across the gender groups in other settings (e.g., Nien & Duda, 2008; Wang, Biddle, & Elliot, 2007).

According to Clark and Watson (1995), our confidence in the construct validity of achievement goals will be greater if research studies provide evidence that goals relate to other constructs in predictable ways and with similar strengths across cultures. It would be very informative and valuable for researchers and practitioners if future studies continue to examine the associations between achievement goals and other closely related but distinct constructs such as motives (Tanaka et al., 2002; Tanaka &Yamauchi, 2001), task values (Eccles, 2005; Liem, Lau, & Nie, 2008), achievement emotions (Pekrun, Elliot, & Maier, 2009), and competence perceptions (Cury, Da Fonséca, Rufo, & Sarrazin, 2002) across cultures. With the increasing interest in cross-cultural research on achievement goals, more effort should be placed on cross-cultural validation studies of instruments measuring achievement goals in new populations, cultural groups, and instructional and evaluative contexts, with the goal of improving their sound use and interpretations.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Huaping Sun is a visiting assistant professor at the University of Memphis. She received her PhD in Educational Psychology from the University of Arizona. Her areas of professional interest include psychometrics, professional licensure, achievement motivation, and evaluation of psychological and educational tests’ reliability and validity evidence.

Diley Hernandez received her PhD in Educational Psychology from the University of Arizona. She is the Project Director of the GoSTEM initiative at the Center for the Enhancement of Teaching and Learning, Georgia Institute of Technology. Her research interests include educational psychology, motivation, cultural studies in education, and learning and teaching.
